Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I was sitting on the poolside bench, my phone buzzing with texts from Emily. She was upset—apparently, I’d forgotten we were supposed to go hiking this weekend, and now she thought I didn’t care. I could feel the tension in her words, the expectation that I’d drop everything and reassure her, fix things before they got worse. But as I started typing a reply, I caught movement out of the corner of my eye. A group of teenagers was gathering at the deep end, laughing and edging dangerously close to the no-diving signs. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my head: “No exceptions. Safety first.” I knew I had to act, to enforce the rules before someone got hurt. But Emily’s messages kept coming, each one more urgent, and I felt torn in two—my responsibility to her pulling me one way, my duty as a lifeguard pulling me the other. My heart pounded as I stood up, phone in hand, caught between the demands of the person I loved and the lives I was supposed to protect.
